[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Function: fuzz_post_handshake()] [Message length exploitation] Can fuzz data with malformed length fields cause integer overflows when calculating plaintext size, leading to heap corruption in the decryption buffer allocation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Function: fuzz_post_handshake()] [Async abort safety] If the async block at lines 199-202 is aborted mid-execution, could this leave NoiseStream in an inconsistent state where subsequent messages decrypt with corrupted keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Function: fuzz_post_handshake()] [Partial read handling] Does fuzzing test for partial encrypted frames that require multiple read() calls, or can an attacker exploit message fragmentation to cause state machine violations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Function: test_noise_fuzzers()] [Cross-contamination] Can using resp_msg for both fuzz_initiator and fuzz_post_handshake at lines 216-217 cause the fuzzers to miss vulnerabilities specific to initiator messages versus post-handshake encrypted messages? [File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Integration: ReadWriteTestSocket] [Socket behavior] Can malicious peers exploit differences between ReadWriteTestSocket and real network sockets to perform attacks that work on production validators but are missed by fuzzing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Async execution] [Race conditions] Can concurrent fuzz execution with block_on() cause race conditions in shared state (like KEYPAIRS) that lead to inconsistent cryptographic material across handshakes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Async execution] [Executor choice] Does using block_on from futures executor versus Tokio in production cause different async scheduling behavior that could hide timing vulnerabilities in the handshake protocol? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Memory safety] [Unsafe code] Are there any unsafe blocks in the Noise protocol implementation that fuzzing could trigger to cause memory corruption vulnerabilities like use-after-free or double-free? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Memory safety] [Buffer overflow] Can fuzz data cause buffer overflows when copying handshake messages or encrypted payloads, potentially allowing remote code execution on validator nodes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Error propagation] [Panic vs Result] Does the fuzzing harness properly distinguish between panics (programming errors) and Result errors (protocol violations), or could an attacker exploit panic paths to crash validators? (High)
